answer_html: Since \(\displaystyle \sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{1}{n^4}=\displaystyle \sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{1}{n^4}\) converges, by limit comparison our series also converges.
answer_latex:
Since $\displaystyle \sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{1}{n^4}=\displaystyle \sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{1}{n^4}$ converges, by
limit comparison our series also converges.
hints_html:
Use the fact that sums of the form

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle \sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{1}{n^k}\end{aligned}\]

converge for \(k > 1\)

Use a comparison test with a series like \(\displaystyle \sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{1}{n^k}\). How about k=4?

Use the fact that

\(-1 \leq \sin(n) \leq 1\)
hints_latex:
Use a comparison test with a series like
$\displaystyle \sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{1}{n^k}$. How about \emph{k=4}?
hints_raw:
Use the fact that sums of the form
:<math>\displaystyle \sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{1}{n^k} </math>
converge for <math>k > 1</math>
Use a comparison test with a series like <math>\displaystyle \sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{1}{n^k} </math>. How about ''k=4''?
Use the fact that 

<math> -1 \leq \sin(n) \leq 1 </math>
question: 4 (a)
sols_html:
We will compare our series with \(\displaystyle \sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{1}{n^4} .\) So we look at the limit:

\[\begin{aligned} \lim_{n\to \infty} \frac{(\frac{n^2-\sin(n)}{n^6+n^2})}{(\frac{1}{n^4})} &= \lim_{n\to \infty}\frac{n^6+n^4\sin(n)}{n^6+n^2} \\ &=\lim_{n\to \infty}\frac{1-\frac{\sin(n)}{n^2}}{1+\frac{1}{n^4}} \\ &=\frac{1}{1}=1\end{aligned}\]

Since \(\displaystyle \sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{1}{n^4}\) converges, by limit comparison our series also converges.
sols_latex:
We will compare our series with
$\displaystyle \sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{1}{n^4} .$ So we look at the
limit:

\begin{align*}
\lim_{n\to \infty} \frac{(\frac{n^2-\sin(n)}{n^6+n^2})}{(\frac{1}{n^4})} &= \lim_{n\to \infty}\frac{n^6+n^4\sin(n)}{n^6+n^2} \\
&=\lim_{n\to \infty}\frac{1-\frac{\sin(n)}{n^2}}{1+\frac{1}{n^4}} \\
&=\frac{1}{1}=1
\end{align*}

Since $\displaystyle \sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{1}{n^4}$ converges, by
limit comparison our series also converges.
sols_raw:
We will compare our series with <math> \displaystyle \sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{1}{n^4} .</math> So we look at the limit:

:<math>
\begin{align}
\lim_{n\to \infty} \frac{(\frac{n^2-\sin(n)}{n^6+n^2})}{(\frac{1}{n^4})} &= \lim_{n\to \infty}\frac{n^6+n^4\sin(n)}{n^6+n^2} \\
&=\lim_{n\to \infty}\frac{1-\frac{\sin(n)}{n^2}}{1+\frac{1}{n^4}} \\
&=\frac{1}{1}=1
\end{align}
</math>

Since <math> \displaystyle \sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{1}{n^4} </math> converges, by limit comparison our series also converges.
statement_html:
Determine, with explanation, whether the series

\[\begin{aligned} \sum_{n=1}^{\infty}\frac{n^{2}-\sin n}{n^{6}+n^{2}}\end{aligned}\]

converges or diverges.
statement_raw:
Determine, with explanation, whether the series 

:<math>
\sum_{n=1}^{\infty}\frac{n^{2}-\sin n}{n^{6}+n^{2}}
</math>

converges or diverges.
